definition: to give up one's private interests for the public good (idiom); to behave altruistically/selfless and public spirited
residence
old variant of 捨|舍[she3]
surname She
to give up/to abandon/to give alms
self/oneself/sixth of the ten Heavenly Stems 十天干[shi2 tian1 gan1]/sixth in order/letter "F" or Roman "VI" in list "A, B, C", or "I, II, III" etc/hexa
variant of 為|为[wei4], because of/for/to
because of/for/to
variant of 為|为[wei2]/as (i.e. in the capacity of)/to take sth as/to act as/to serve as/to behave as/to become/to be/to do
as (in the capacity of)/to take sth as/to act as/to serve as/to behave as/to become/to be/to do/by (in the passive voice)

public/collectively owned/common/international (e.g. high seas, metric system, calendar)/make public/fair/just/Duke, highest of five orders of nobility 五等爵位[wu3 deng3 jue2 wei4]/honorable (gentlemen)/father-in-law/male (animal)
for the common good and forgetting personal interests (idiom); to behave altruistically/selfless
self-restraint and devotion to public duties (idiom); selfless dedication/to serve the public interest wholeheartedly
selfless/impartial
to abandon self for others (idiom, from Analects); to sacrifice one's own interest for other people/altruism
to abandon self for others (idiom); to sacrifice oneself to help the people/altruism
to give up life for righteousness (idiom, from Mencius); to choose honor over life/would rather sacrifice one's life than one's principles
bravery with no thought of personal safety (idiom); risking life and limb/undaunted by perils
lit. to open one's liver and drip gall (idiom); wholehearted loyalty
of noble character and unquestionable integrity (idiom)
to abandon one's body in the search for Buddha's truth (idiom)
lit. red-bellied devotion (idiom); wholehearted loyalty/to serve sb with body and soul
to bend to a task and spare no effort (idiom); striving to the utmost
to dress before light and not eat before dark (idiom)/diligently attending to official matters
utterly fearless
until death puts an end (idiom); one's whole life/unto one's dying day
lit. both sleeves flowing in the breeze (idiom); having clean hands/uncorrupted/unsoiled by corrupt practices
